metadata.case_name: Podar Plastics Pvt. Ltd. v. Its Workmen

facts.text: Appeal arises from industrial dispute between appellant Podar Plastics Pvt. Ltd. and respondents (its workmen) regarding claim for bonus for the year 1959.
Respondents claimed bonus equivalent to three months salary including dearness allowance.
Industrial Tribunal, Maharashtra, in Reference IT No. 43 of 1961, awarded bonus at rate of half months basic wages excluding allowances and overtime for 1959, vide award dated August 26, 1961.
Appellant is private company with registered office at Podar Chambers, Parsee Bazar Street, Fort, Bombay; owns factory at Supari Baug Road manufacturing plastic products.
Gross profits for relevant year admitted at Rs. 2.70 lacs.
Tribunal calculated available surplus as Rs. 0.44 lac (statutory depreciation) or Rs. 0.33 lac (notional normal depreciation as claimed by appellant).
Court accepts alternative calculation with corrections: notional depreciation Rs. 0.73 lac (not 0.78 lac), income-tax Rs. 0.95 lac (not 0.96 lac), making available surplus Rs. 0.39 lac.
Appellant claimed deduction of Rs. 60,000 as notional remuneration for Director K.R. Podar at Rs. 5,000 per month for full-time supervision.

Appellant is private ltd. company; major shareholders are Podar family members (R.A. Podar, G.R. Podar, K.R. Podar, B.J. Podar), Ms. Podar Trading Co. Pvt. Ltd., Jay Agents Pvt. Ltd., National Traders Pvt. Ltd., Ratilal B. Desai.
Manager Mr. Gupta's affidavit: K.R. Podar attends factory 9 A.M.-1 P.M. and 2:30 P.M.-6:30 P.M.; offered for cross-examination.
No board resolution passed for K.R. Podar's remuneration unlike previous director (Rs. 1000/month); no actual remuneration charged due to company's financial position.
Tribunal rejected deduction for notional remuneration to K.R. Podar; did not accept Mr. Gupta's evidence fully; K.R. Podar did not testify.
Appellant claimed rehabilitation of Rs. 8,84,629; began business with second-hand machinery; evidence by Mr. Dinshaw rejected as unreliable; included dead stock claim rejected.
Tribunal held no claim for rehabilitation as second-hand machinery should be replaced by second-hand, not new.
No material on record to determine wealth tax amount paid or charged.

legal_issues.text: Whether notional normal depreciation (as claimed by appellant) should be deducted as prior charge instead of statutory depreciation under Full Bench Formula.
Whether Rs. 60,000 notional remuneration to Director K.R. Podar deductible as prior charge.
Whether appellant entitled to rehabilitation allowance, particularly with second-hand machinery.
Whether deduction for wealth tax allowable.

petitioner_arguments.text: No available surplus per Full Bench Formula if proper accounts made; disputes prior charges deductions.
Notional normal depreciation (Rs. 0.78 lac, corrected to 0.73 lac) should be deducted.
Rs. 60,000 notional remuneration to K.R. Podar deductible as he devoted full time to management.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Gujarat Engineering Company v. Ahmedabad Misc. Industrial Workers Union; Kodaneri Estate v. Its Workmen

petitioner_arguments.text: Rehabilitation claim of Rs. 8,84,629 allowable even for second-hand machinery replaced by new.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: South India Millowners Association v. Coimbatore District Textile Workers Union

petitioner_arguments.text: Deduction for wealth tax should be allowed.
Tribunal should allow some ad hoc rehabilitation.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: South India Millowners Association v. Coimbatore District Textile Workers Union

respondent_arguments.text: Working of Full Bench Formula shows substantial available surplus allowing three months wages as bonus.

court_reasoning.text: Accepts appellant's alternative calculation of available surplus as Rs. 0.39 lac after corrections, which favors appellant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal's calculation had errors in favor of appellant.

court_reasoning.text: Notional remuneration to K.R. Podar not deductible as not actually charged or paid; no resolution; hypothetical claims not permissible to depress surplus; Tribunal disbelieved evidence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reasonable remuneration allowable if actually paid and shown in accounts, per precedents.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal erred in holding second-hand machinery rehabilitated only by second-hand; but rejected claim on reliability of evidence by Mr. Dinshaw and other reasons; no interference as appreciation of evidence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Opportunity given for better evidence in future.

court_reasoning.text: No ad hoc rehabilitation where evidence insufficient and rejected; South India Millowners did not approve ad hoc basis.
Wealth tax deduction not allowable due to no material on amount.

holdings.text: Director entitled to reasonable remuneration as prior charge if actually paid and shown in accounts; not if purely notional.
Rehabilitation for second-hand machinery can be on basis of new replacement; but claim rejected on evidence.
No mandatory ad hoc rehabilitation allowance without evidence.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gujarat Engineering Company v. Ahmedabad Misc. Industrial Workers Union
precedents_cited.relevance: Director entitled to reasonable remuneration if spends time supervising and managing.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kodaneri Estate v. Its Workmen and Another
precedents_cited.relevance: Director entitled to reasonable remuneration if spends time supervising and managing.

precedents_cited.case_name: South India Millowners Association and Ors. v. Coimbatore District Textile Workers Union and Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Rejected view that second-hand machinery rehabilitated only by second-hand; did not approve ad hoc basis.

statutes_cited.name: Full Bench Formula
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for calculating available surplus for bonus; prior charges like depreciation, remuneration, rehabilitation, taxes.

outcome.summary: Appeal against Tribunal's award of half month's basic wages as bonus upheld; rejections of notional remuneration, rehabilitation, and wealth tax claims affirmed; corrections to surplus noted but no change in award.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; Tribunal award stands.

key_quotes.text: "It would not be permissible for the employer to make it still more notional by introducing claims for prior charges on purely hypothetical and almost fictional basis."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The inclusion of such an item solely for the purpose of depressing the available surplus cannot, in our opinion, be allowed."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "If the employer does not adduce sufficient evidence to justify his claim for rehabilitation and the Tribunal is inclined to reject the evidence which has been adduced, the Tribunal must nevertheless award some rehabilitation on a purely hypothetical and imaginary ad hoc basis."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: No ad hoc rehabilitation without evidence.
